author: NEW YORK DAILY NEWS
title: Love and tears at Manhattan doorman’s funeral
text:
Upper East Side doorman Miguel Gonzalez, who died in last week’s snowstorm , was remembered Monday for his infectious smile and commitment to his faith.
Family and friends packed Iglesia Cristiana Renacer in Bridgeport, Conn., along with the city’s mayor and police chief, to say goodbye to the man who slipped in snow Thursday and fell through a plate glass window. The happily married grandfather, who would have celebrated his 37th wedding anniversary on Valentine’s Day, lay in a light blue open casket under a large white veil.
“He’s looking down and he’s happy,” niece Lysette Colon told the Daily News. “He’s here right now, and I know he’s smiling, and he’s saying, ‘My people are together. This is what I love the most.’ ”
Fellow choir members sang three of Gonzalez’s favorite songs in Spanish as a mannequin draped in his blue choir robe stood nearby in tribute.
Feds to probe site where doorman died by falling into window 
Miguel Gonzalez's wife Elena Gonzalez (r.) is comforted at his funeral. (Angus Mordant/for New York Daily News) Colon said the veil was necessary to conceal the injury the 59-year-old Gonzalez suffered after the accident in front of the building where he worked on E. 93rd St. near First Ave.
“We couldn’t have people touch or try to kiss his face. There was a lot of scarring,” she said. The grieving niece said Gonzalez’s wife, Elena, 66, was “holding up” amid her unspeakable heartbreak. Instead of preparing for a Valentine’s Day anniversary celebration, she was set to fly to Puerto Rico on Tuesday along with her husband’s casket for another service and burial there.
Gonzalez was clearing snow when he slipped on the steps and fell through the brittle glass window about 9:30 a.m., witnesses and officials said. An autopsy confirmed he died after glass shards severed his jugular vein.
Funeral program for Miguel Gonzalez. (Obtained by the News) The U.S. Consumer Product Safety Commission will investigate whether safety glass should have been installed instead, an agency spokesman told The News on Friday. The building is owned by Mount Sinai Hospital to house physician residents, officials said.
Doorman dies after he slips on snow, crashes through UES window 
“If you think he was loved by the public,” wife Elena told The News on Friday, “as his wife, my love for him was immense and unconditional.”
